Dear Susan Joy Mitchell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
Description child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's
placement at least once every month.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation During the month of May 2024, there were several staff that ended
their employment with the agency. One staff that ended their
employment on 5/31/24 did not meet their face-to-face
requirements with the children on their caseload. It was reported
that leadership was not certain at the end of May 2024 if children
had been seen and did not require staff still employed at the
agency, to go see children, in the event that they had not been
seen.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Key Performance Indicator (KPI) Analyst for Samaritas-
Southwest was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024. She reported
during a monthly metric meeting with leadership staff from
Samaritas-Southwest in June of 2024, KPI Analyst pulled a report
of worker/child visits for May and noticed there were several
missing for Foster Care Worker’s caseload. She stated she met
with leadership staff from the agency again on June 18th, at which
time KPI Analyst was told the visits must just not have been
entered yet at the time she pulled the report. KPI Analyst followed
up with the agency Program Manager on June 20th who told KPI
Analyst all the caregiver’s had been called and it was confirmed
that the missing worker/child visits did not occur. KPI Analyst was
concerned as it did not sound as if there was a plan made for all
the youths who had not been seen by a worker to be seen
immediately.
Program Manager was interviewed virtually on 6/25/2024. He
reported he began supervising Foster Care Worker on April 22,
2024, after a foster care supervisor left unexpectedly. He stated
when he met with Foster Care Worker for supervision during the
month of May to discuss her worker/child visits she reported all
visits were either completed or were scheduled to occur for the
month. He stated he didn’t check her case contacts at the time
and didn’t have any concerns that would cause him to believe she
wasn’t being honest. He stated he was new to supervision at that
2

time and hadn’t yet established a process for tracking his staff’s
work completion. Program Manager stated Foster Care Worker
went on vacation for a week in May after which she took another
unplanned week off due to her father being ill. He stated she no
showed for work 2 or 3 days then quit on May 31, 2024, by
emailing Program Manager at night. He stated he was present for
the meeting with KPI Analyst at which time he learned of the
missing worker/child visits for the youths on Foster Care Worker’s
caseload. He stated he looked for home visits forms that might
have been completed by Foster Care Worker but was unable to
locate any after which the workers who were assigned to each of
those cases started calling the caregivers to find out if Foster Care
Worker had visited the youths in their homes. He stated most of
the youth’s had not been seen in May, but all the youths were
seen in June.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• KPI Analyst provided a list of 11 youths not seen in May or
June as of June 20,2024. Those youths, Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, Youth F, Youth G, Youth H,
Youth I, Youth J, Youth K, were all assigned to Foster Care
Worker.
• A review of case contact within each of the identified
youth’s case record documented the following visits with
each youth and their respective caregiver in May of 2024:
o Youth A - None
o Youth B - None
o Youth C - None
o Youth D - None
o Youth E- None
o Youth F – 31st
o Youth G -24th
o Youth H - None
o Youth I - None
o Youth J - None
o Youth K - None
• A review of case contact within each of the identified
youth’s case record documented the following visits with
each youth and their respective caregiver in June of 2024:
o Youth A – 25th
o Youth B - 26th
o Youth C – 26th
o Youth D – 26th
o Youth E – 25th

o Youth F – 21st
o Youth G – 21st
o Youth H – 19th
o Youth I – 27th
o Youth J - 28th
o Youth K – 28th
Analysis The agency is in violation as a social service worker did not visit
nine foster children or their foster parent in the foster parent’s
home in the month of May 2024.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as R 400.12421(b))

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
